Feathers of Despair: City's Pigeons Suffering Unprecedented Rates of Existential Dread, Study Finds

BY DR. BARNABY FINCH, LEAD ORNITHOLOGICAL PSYCHOLOGIST

They are the silent witnesses to our urban sprawl, the stoic observers of our daily commutes. But who watches the watchers? A groundbreaking, privately-funded study released yesterday reveals a startling epidemic sweeping through the city’s pigeon population: Pigeon Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PPTSD).

Our research, conducted over three years at the Finch Institute for Avian Reconciliation, indicates that 93% of urban pigeons exhibit symptoms of severe anxiety, including compulsive pecking, erratic flight patterns, and a profound, often misunderstood, disinterest in artisanal sourdough bread crusts.

"We've seen things you people wouldn't believe. Attack ships on fire off the shoulder of Orion. We've also seen a man in a hot dog costume weep openly on a Tuesday. It all takes a toll."

"These are not merely 'flying rats'," I explained during a sparsely attended press conference. "They are living archives of our collective municipal sorrow. They see tourists with selfie sticks. They see failed parallel parking attempts. They bear witness to every dropped ice cream cone. This constant exposure to low-grade human tragedy has a cumulative, soul-crushing effect."

To combat this crisis, the Institute has opened the world's first therapeutic center for pigeons, featuring a live, 24/7 jazz ensemble to provide "a calming soundscape of post-bop improvisations." Early results are promising, though progress is occasionally hampered by our feline accounts manager, Mr. Scat, who has a habit of 'auditing' invoices directly from the keyboard.

OP-ED

Stop Calling Us 'Flying Rats'

By "A Concerned Pigeon"

We have a rich history. We delivered messages for empires. We are masters of aerial navigation. We can find a single dropped french fry in a 10-acre park. A little respect, please. We are Columba livia domestica, not some common sewer-dwelling rodent with wings.
